Graphical abstract A comparison is made in this study of the effectiveness of various commercial catalysts in the oxidation of NO x by heterogeneous photocatalysis. The following catalysts were considered: Aeroxide TiO2 P25, Aeroxide TiO2 P90, Hombikat UV-100, Kronos vlp7000, CristalACTIV PC105, CristalACTIV PC500, Kemira 650 and Anatasa Aldrich. All catalysts were deposited by a dip-coating technique onto borosilicate 3.3 glass plates. Optimization of catalyst load showed no significant enhancement of photoactivity, in general, above a deposited mass of 1.16mgcm−2. Differences between photocatalyst activity were more apparent at longer illumination times. Photoactivity decreased in the presence of humidity and differences in the adsorbed products were detected. Photocatalyst activity was strongly influenced by specific surface area, with the best results obtained by the catalysts with the largest surface area, namely the PC500, Hombikat and Kronos. Photocatalyst stability was demonstrated in successive reuse cycles. Keywords NO x Photocatalysis TiO2 Dip-coating 1 Introduction Environmental contamination is a major concern in the world today. One such source of contamination is the presence of so-called “greenhouse gases”, the most important of which are NO x , CO2, CH4, O3, and SO2. The anthropogenic generation of the NO x group of gases, which are among the most hazardous, is a growing problem. Combustion, in many industrial activities as well as in many forms of transport, is the main source of emission of this group of gases into the atmosphere [1]. NO x gases are pollutants responsible for causing acid rain and photochemical smog, both of which can lead to damaging respiratory problems [2,3]. Mankind’s increasing industrial activity has led to the emission of more and more of these harmful gases. Though research continues into suitable treatment methods, their emission should ideally be prevented or at least reduced at source. Heterogeneous photocatalysis, one of several possible treatment techniques, has been extensively studied and is considered an efficient and economic method for converting NO x into non-toxic species [3–9]. It is known that NO x gases can easily be oxidized under radiation in the presence of TiO2 and oxygen molecules [3,4,10–13] to ionic species as the final product of oxidation. This photocatalytic treatment begins by irradiating the catalyst with an appropriate radiation wavelength, at or below its band gap. The excitation radiation of TiO2-based catalysts, which are the type most commonly applied in photocatalytic NO x oxidation, must be ≤400nm. At that instant, electrons of the valence band become excited and transferred to the conduction band, generating an electron–hole pair that is able to initiate the redox reaction or can recombine. If the redox reaction is initiated the reactions that are produced are able to transform the NO into NO3 − (Eqs. (1)–(8)) [10,14]. Eqs. (1)–(3) show the reactions of the photocatalysis process in the presence of oxygen when the TiO2 receives the incident radiation. (1) Ti O 2 + h v → Ti O 2 ( e CB − + h VB − ) (2) HO ( ads ) − + h VB + → HO ( ads ) (3) O 2 ( ads ) + e CB − → O 2 ( ads ) − Eqs. (4)–(6) correspond to NO oxidation, which is either due to hydroxyl radicals (Eqs. (4) and (5)) and takes place in two steps (from NO to NO2 and from NO2 to NO3 −) or to the action of the superoxide radical with the direct generation of nitrates (Eq. (6)): (4) N O ( ads ) + 2 H O ( ads ) → N O 2 ( ads ) + H 2 O ( ads ) (5) N O 2 ( ads ) + H O ( ads ) → N O 3 ( ads ) − + H ( ads ) + (6) NO x ( ads ) → O 2 − N O 3 ( ads ) − At the same time, the unwanted reaction of disproportionation of the NO2 through the action of hydroxide anions can take place (Eq. (7)). (7) 3 N O 2 + 2 O H − → 2 N O 3 − + N O + H 2 O Finally, the nitrate anions that are generated and adsorbed onto the photoactive surface could be eliminated from the surface by a washing action, which can occur naturally as a result of rainwater or humidity (Eq. (8)). In this way, surface acidification (which could cause deactivation of the catalyst) is prevented. (8) HN O 3 ( ads) → HN O 3 ( aq ) The NO x degradation mechanism, represented in Eqs. (1)–(8), clearly shows that the efficiency of the catalyst in the process depends directly on the radiation and on the presence of oxygen and water molecules adsorbed onto the surface of the photocatalyst [2,13,15]. The application of photocatalysis in the elimination of NO x has progressed beyond the R&D stage. Today, it is a technique that is used with several marketed products. Although an ISO standard was published in 2007 (ISO 22197-1:2007) as a first step towards test standardization, it is lacking in certain aspects and there is ample room for further product development and improvement through the appropriate selection of the initial catalyst. In view of the above, it was decided to compare eight commercial catalysts (Aeroxide TiO2 P25, Aeroxide TiO2 P90, Hombikat UV-100, Kronos vlp7000, CristalACTIV PC105, CristalACTIV PC500, Kemira 650 and Anatasa Aldrich) which are commonly used in photocatalysis studies [16–18]. The aim of this comparison is to determine the structural characteristics of a photocatalyst that most favor degradation of NO x gases. The catalyst loads were optimized on borosilicate plates and studies were carried out to determine the effect of humidity and the level of photoactivity in the visible region of the spectrum. An analysis was also carried out of the performance of the most efficient photocatalysts in consecutive reuse cycles. In short, this study aims to determine the most suitable photocatalysts for photo-oxidation of NO x gases and, by doing so, to provide a series of criteria for the selection of appropriate materials for the manufacture of commercial products designed for this purpose. 2 Experimental 2.1 Dip-coating The following commercial photocatalysts were used to compare efficiency in NO x degradation: Aeroxide TiO2 P25 (P25), Aeroxide TiO2 P90 (P90), Hombikat UV-100 (Hombikat), Kronos vlp7000 (Kronos), CristalACTIV PC105 (PC105), CristalACTIV PC500 (PC500), Kemira 650 (Kemira) and Anatasa Aldrich (Aldrich). The catalysts were deposited onto previously washed 50cm2 borosilicate 3.3 plates with a dip-coating procedure (KSV-DC Dip-Coater). The plates were introduced into a 50gL−1 suspension of the catalyst in methanol at a rate of 500mmmin−1, left in the suspension for 20s and withdrawn at a rate of 120mmmin-1. These cycles were repeated in each case until the desired catalyst mass had been reached. After conclusion of the depositing process, the plates were dried at 373K for 2h. The following deposits were obtained: 0.24±0.01, 0.52±0.01, 1.16±0.01, 1.68±0.01 and 1.92±0.01mgcm−2. 2.2 Analysis techniques Phase composition and crystal sizes were estimated from XRD patterns recorded on a PANalytical X’Pert diffractometer equipped with a Ni filter and X’Celerator detector using Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.5418Å). Diffuse reflectance spectra were recorded for all samples on a Varian Cary 5 and the Kubelka–Munk function, F (R ∞), was applied to obtain band-gap energies following the method proposed by Tandon and Gupta [19]. BET surface area and pore volume by the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method were determined using N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms at 77K measured with a Micromeritics 2010 system. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) images were obtained using a Hitachi S-4800 microscope in order to determine the thickness of the deposit on the plates. The method described in ASTM Standard D3330/D3330M using the ASTM D3359 tape test was employed to determine adherence. To obtain further information about the deposits on the plates the samples were also analyzed by AFM (Atomic Force Microscopy) using Nanoscope V Multimode equipment (Digital Instruments, Santa Barbara, California). Images were taken in air at room temperature and at a scanning rate of 1Hz with etched silicon tips (RTESP, 215–254kHz and 20–80N/m). A Thermo Scientific-Nicolet iS10 spectrophotometer was used for the FTIR studies. The catalyst was placed between two CaF2 mirrors and a 4000–1000cm−1 measurement range, 2cm−1 resolution and forward/backward mirror speeds of 10kHz/6.2kHz, respectively, were used. 2.3 Photoactivity study Fig. 1 is a schematic representation of the configuration for the photoactivity tests. The desired concentration of NO x was obtained from dilution with air of a 100ppm concentration of NO (supplied by Air Liquide) using mass flow controllers. For the addition of humidity, an extra air line was used which passed through a thermostatically controlled water bath. Humidity levels were controlled using a Rotronic Hygropalm probe. The 3.3 borosilicate glass plate (10×5cm) was placed inside the reactor (made from nylon). The gas flow travelling through the empty reactor volume (0.26mL) was of turbulent regime. Total work flow was 1.2Lmin−1 at 1atm and reactor residence time was 0.13s. The tests began after 30min of adsorption onto the deposited photocatalyst in darkness followed by illumination during 60min or 24h. The light source employed was a 10Wm−2 Osram Ultra Vitalux 300W lamp. A Schott filter (cut-off wavelength 400nm) was placed between the reactor and the lamp for the tests with visible light. Quantification of NO x was performed using a Horiba APNA-370 N/S analyzer. The results are expressed as percentages of degraded NO ([NO](%)) and selectivity of NO degradation to ionic species (S): [ N O ] ( % ) = [ NO ] in − [ NO ] out [ NO ] in × 100 S = 1 − ( [ N O 2 ] out [ NO ] in − [ NO ] out ) where [NO]in is the NO concentration after 30min of adsorption and [NO]out and [NO2]out are the concentrations at the end of the illumination period. All concentrations are expressed in molarities. After conclusion of the test and in order to determine the concentration of nitrates generated, the plates were subjected to a washing process with 100mL of MilliQ water for 1h. The wash water was analyzed with a DIONEX Ionic Chromatograph equipped with a GP50 gradient pump and an ED50 electrochemical detector. A CS11A column (4mm×250mm) was used with eluent consisting of 60mM of NaOH and a flow rate of 1mLmin−1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization Table 1 shows the basic characteristics of the catalysts [20]. One of the selected photocatalysts is 100% rutile phase (Kemira), five are 100% anatase phase and two present both phases (P25 and P90, each with 20% rutile and 80% anatase). Of the 100% anatase phase photocatalysts, Aldrich has a surface area similar to that of P25, PC105 a surface area similar to that of P90, while Hombikat, Kronos and PC500 have by far the largest surface areas of 202, 259 and 358m2 g−1, respectively. P90 crystal size is approximately half that of P25 in both anatase and rutile phase. The catalysts with only anatase phase have the smallest crystal size, 7nm for PC500 and Kronos and a slightly larger size for Hombikat. The largest size of crystal was found for the Kemira photocatalyst. The band-gap values of all the materials were between the values expected for anatase and rutile phases [21]. Fig. 2 shows SEM images of the deposited photocatalysts. Note how the deposit on the borosilicate plate is comprised of continuous layers only for the P25, P90 and Aldrich photocatalysts. For the other photocatalysts, the particles do not form a continuous layer but are found in the form of isolated aggregates distributed over the glass plate; they can be described as being less compact and of more irregular layers. This type of photocatalyst particle aggregation can be interpreted as a greater tendency of the particles to interact among themselves as opposed to with the glass plate surface. It would also seem, based on this observation, that greater layer continuity is favored in those catalyst samples with a smaller specific surface area and, subsequently, a higher average particle size. It is seen that adherence for catalysts with a smaller particle size is slightly worse. The tests performed to ASTM Standard D3330/D3330M showed that the P25 deposit of 1.16±0.01mgcm−2 displayed an average level of adherence, whereas adherence was low for the same deposited amount of the PC500 catalyst. AFM images were obtained of the photocatalysts with strongest adherence to the support. Fig. 3 shows the images for the P25 and P90 catalysts. It can be seen that the P25 layer (Root Mean Square roughness, RMS=457.72±60.61nm) is slightly rougher than the P90 layer (RMS=348.98±37.07nm). 3.2 Effect of the nature and load of the catalyst Fig. 4 shows the activity of each of the photocatalysts for 1h of illumination time as a function of deposited mass. It can be seen for the P25 that degradation and selectivity increased significantly up to a deposit of 1.16±0.01mgcm−2, where respective values of 94.8% and 0.94 were obtained. Better results were obtained for the P90, a catalyst with very similar crystal phase ratio to the P25 but a larger surface area. A degradation rate of 90.4% and a selectivity value of 0.80 were obtained for the P90 at the lowest tested deposit of 0.24mgcm−2 compared to corresponding values of 75.7% and 0.53 for the P25. At these low loads, the Aldrich catalyst also obtained better results than the P25. In short, the P90 performed slightly better than the P25 and Aldrich photocatalysts. However, if the P90 is compared with a catalyst like the PC105, which has a similar specific surface area, then the PC105 had better results for the lower loads and the P90 slightly better results for loads of 1.16±0.01mgcm−2 and above. The Hombikat and PC500 catalysts, with high specific surface areas, showed the best results at loads below 1.16±0.01mgcm−2. At higher loads, as with the PC105, these photocatalysts maintained a high and constant activity. Despite a difference between their specific surface areas of more than 150m2 g−1, no significant differences in photoactivity were observed between the Hombikat and PC500 catalysts under the test conditions. The results obtained with the samples deposited with the Kronos photocatalyst showed degradations below 80% up to a load of 0.52±0.01mgcm−2, though selectivity was always higher than 0.95. The 100% rutile phase catalysts appeared to have practically no activity in oxidation of NO x gases as occurs with the oxidation of organic pollutants [22], presumably due to the low production of hydroxyl radicals of catalysts with this crystalline structure [23]. In this case, the degradation rates did not exceed 10% for a load of 0.52±0.01mgcm−2 [2,24]. In summary, under the test conditions, the best results were obtained for the P90, PC105, Hombikat and PC500 catalysts. In addition, it seems that with a deposited mass of 1.16±0.01mgcm−2 all the photocatalysts attained optimum NO x oxidation. As a result, this was the load chosen for testing of all the photocatalysts for longer periods of illumination and not basing the activities on initial and non-equilibrium profiles [25]. Fig. 5 a shows the results for 24h of illumination. The increase in illumination time resulted in a decrease in activity of all photocatalysts in terms of both degradation percentage and selectivity, though the effect was more noticeable for selectivity. The least affected photocatalysts were the PC500 and Hombikat, with respective values of [NO]/%=88.1 and S =0.75 and [NO]/%=87.4 and S =0.64. The most strongly affected photocatalysts in terms of selectivity were the P25, Aldrich, P90 and PC105, with values in all cases below 0.38. The Kronos photocatalyst suffered a significant drop in degradation percentage, but maintained a selectivity value of 0.59. Though a steady state was obtained for the P25, Aldrich, P90 and PC105 (Fig. 6 ), the catalysts are not simple NO to NO2 converters. After 24h, the selectivities, though low, are not at zero, indicating that the photocatalysts continue to act as NO x removers under the study conditions. In summary, the longer illumination time revealed an effect that was not so apparent in the short tests, namely the importance of surface area in comparison with other factors like, for example, the crystal phase ratio. PC500 gave the best results, followed closely by Hombikat which has a surface area more than 150m2 g−1 smaller than PC500. Nitrate content as measured in the wash water of the samples was very small. The highest and lowest values of 0.058 and 0.012mmol, respectively, corresponded to the PC500 and Aldrich catalysts. 3.3 Effect of humidity Tests using all the photocatalysts with a deposited mass of 1.16±0.01mgcm−2 were performed with 1h illumination for three selected humidities: 25%, 40% and 65% (Table 2 ). In general, a slight trend was observed of a decrease in degradation percentage as humidity rises, though even at 65% humidity the values of degradation percentage in almost all cases were above 87%. However, selectivity was strongly and negatively affected by humidity in all cases. For the photocatalysts with a smaller surface area, an important decrease in selectivity can be observed at 25% humidity which continues as humidity rises. For the photocatalysts with a larger surface area, the PC500, Hombikat and Kronos, this fall at 25% humidity is not as marked, and though selectivity continues to fall as humidity rises the values remain higher than for the other catalysts. The best results, though by a small margin, were obtained with the Kronos catalyst. The effect of humidity as shown in the results obtained concurs with the behavior observed by other authors [26,27]. The decrease can be explained as the competition between the water and the pollutant for the adsorption centers of the catalyst. The higher the amount of water, the higher the probability that it occupies these centers, with the result that the pollutant cannot be oxidized so effectively. Finally, given that the differences between the photocatalysts were more evident in the dry-air tests when using longer periods of illumination, the catalysts with the highest photoactivity were tested with 65% humidity and 24h of illumination. As can be seen in Fig. 5b, the best degradation and selectivity results were obtained with the Kronos catalyst (75.7% and 0.45, respectively), followed, in terms of degradation percentage, by the PC500 and in last place the Hombikat. Logically, as selectivity values and degradation percentages were smaller, the concentrations of nitrates measured in the presence of humidity were also lower, in the interval of 0.011–0.026mmol. 3.4 FTIR study The spectra of the catalysts were taken after conclusion of the photoactivity tests and without being subjected to a washing process. Bands of different products can be seen in the tests in the absence of humidity and the tests with 65% humidity. Bands at 1810cm−1 and 1789cm−1 can be seen in both spectra (Fig. 7 a), corresponding to nitric acid–water adducts. Spectra with different HNO3–H2O proportions were taken to verify the nature of these bands (Fig. 7b). However, an additional band at 1570cm−1 attributed to adsorbed nitrates can be seen in the spectrum taken when the test was carried out in the absence of humidity. These differences may be indicating two NO oxidation mechanisms and different photocatalytic activity as a result of the presence or absence of humidity. Further studies are required to analyze this question in greater detail. 3.5 Effect of initial concentration of NO Using the PC500, Hombikat, Kronos and P90 catalysts, the initial concentration of NO was varied (250ppb, 500ppb and 750ppb). Fig. 8 a shows that the amount of oxidized NO increases linearly with the initial NO concentration. Selectivity for all catalysts and concentrations was close to 1. With respect to nitrates (Fig. 8b), the results confirmed the expected increase in the amount of nitrates with the number of degraded moles. 3.6 Effect of catalyst reuse The photocatalysts were also subjected to successive cycles of exposure to NO x , with washes between cycles, to determine the reproducibility of catalyst effectiveness. Though Fig. 9 a only shows the results for the Kronos and PC500 photocatalysts, the test was also performed and showed similar results and conclusions with the Hombikat, P25 and P90 catalysts. In all cases, degradation was higher than 95% and selectivity was 0.98. A wash with water between cycles was sufficient to return the catalyst to its initial activity. When no washing was performed, a slight decrease in activity was observed after 10h of continuous illumination (Fig. 9b). 3.7 Effect of UV or visible light One of the major issues in the application of photocatalysis at pre-industrial scale is the low level of activity with visible light, as only 5% of solar radiation corresponds to UV radiation. This problem acquires even greater importance in the treatment of atmospheric pollutants where, evidently, the activity of the photocatalytic systems takes place under solar radiation and not indoors. With this in mind, the catalysts that displayed the highest activity in the present study, the Hombikat, PC500 and Kronos, were also tested under visible radiation. Fig. 10 shows the activity of these photocatalysts with UV–vis radiation and only visible radiation at 0% (Fig. 10a) and 65% (Fig. 10b) humidity. At 0% humidity, though the selectivity values remained practically unchanged in all 3 catalysts, the degradation percentages of the Hombikat and PC500 catalysts fell significantly in visible light. However, at 65% humidity, selectivity values were considerably lower with visible radiation only and the decreases in degradation percentage were even more marked. According to its makers, the Kronos photocatalyst is a carbon-modified titanium dioxide with activity in the visible range (Patent US2005/0226761A1). This would explain its good performance in visible light, particularly in the absence of humidity. However, the activity of this catalyst under visible radiation is not stable, as has been reported by Quesada-Cabrera et al. [28]. It is known that the carbon species responsible for this activity are degraded under radiation in air. Fig. 11 shows how the catalyst maintained its activity after 5 cycles of illumination in the visible range, but after subjecting it to a longer period of UV–vis illumination in air, activity in the visible range fell considerably. 4 Conclusion The photocatalysts with a smaller surface area and larger-sized particle formed deposits of continuous layers on the borosilicate glass plates, whereas with those of larger surface area isolated aggregates were distributed over the glass plate surface. No significant enhancement in activity was observed above a load of 1.16mgcm−2. Under the dry-air test conditions, the amount of oxidized NO varied linearly with the input flow concentration. Differences between photocatalyst activity were more marked with longer periods of exposure time. Surface area appears to be a determining factor for the activity of the photocatalysts and the best results were obtained with the PC500, Hombikat and Kronos catalysts. PC500 gave marginally the best results in dry air, while Kronos responded slightly better to the presence of humidity and performed well in the visible range. The different products adsorbed on the photocatalyst surface in the presence and absence of humidity seem to indicate differences in the NO x oxidation mechanism. Photocatalyst stability was demonstrated in reuse cycles with washes between cycles. Only small concentrations of nitrates were found, strongly suggesting the formation of other nitrogenated species which to date have not been considered in the photocatalytic oxidation mechanism of NO x gases. coredata.dc:description: A comparison is made in this study of the effectiveness of various commercial catalysts in the oxidation of NO x by heterogeneous photocatalysis. The following catalysts were considered: Aeroxide TiO2 P25, Aeroxide TiO2 P90, Hombikat UV-100, Kronos vlp7000, CristalACTIV PC105, CristalACTIV PC500, Kemira 650 and Anatasa Aldrich. All catalysts were deposited by a dip-coating technique onto borosilicate 3.3 glass plates. Optimization of catalyst load showed no significant enhancement of photoactivity, in general, above a deposited mass of 1.16mgcm−2. Differences between photocatalyst activity were more apparent at longer illumination times. Photoactivity decreased in the presence of humidity and differences in the adsorbed products were detected. Photocatalyst activity was strongly influenced by specific surface area, with the best results obtained by the catalysts with the largest surface area, namely the PC500, Hombikat and Kronos. Photocatalyst stability was demonstrated in successive reuse cycles.
coredata.dc:title: Comparison of supported TiO2 catalysts in the photocatalytic degradation of NO x
